Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Michelle Anne Maier of Oregon Health and Science University to conduct a research project, entitled "Assessing zooplankton grazing on chytrid fungi in Lake Inba, Japan," during the summer of 2012 at Toho University in Funabashi, Chiba, Japan. The host scientist is Dr. Maiko Kagami.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to confirm the role of the mycoloop pathway in the aquatic food web by evaluating grazing of zooplankton on chytrid zoospores in the laboratory and in the field using microscopy and molecular techniques. This work promises to elucidate the role chytrid parasites play in efficiently transferring nutrients from phytoplankton to higher trophic levels.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Under the EAPSI fellowship, I participated in the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS) summer program for 10 weeks in the Department of Environmental Science at Toho University in Narashino, Japan, about thirty minutes east of Tokyo in Chiba prefecture. My project focused on the role of parasites that infect and kill single-celled algae in lakes and rivers play in the food web of these environments. The life cycle of these fungal parasites (‘chytrids’) have both a free-swimming infective stage and an attached parasitic stage. During infection, nutrients are transferred from the algal cell into the attached parasite and then released as infective spores to attach to new cells. These infective spores are also a nutritious food source and can be easily eaten by higher organisms. Due to the fact that these infective spores are often hard to detect because of their small size, it is difficult to know the amount present in the environment and how many are actually being eaten.

During my summer project, I developed a new method to detect these infective spores using quantitative molecular techniques. In order to do this, I first isolated the parasites and algal hosts from Lake Inba, the most eutrophic lake in Japan, and grew the cells in the laboratory. I used the laboratory cultures to create a calibration curve by counting the cells on the microscope and comparing to the amount of DNA detected with a quantitative PCR method (qPCR). The two methods were in good agreement with each other when several spore concentrations were analyzed from 500 cells per milliliter to 70,000 cells per milliliter. Once the quantitative method was developed, I fed the laboratory culture of spores to two species of zooplankton that are thought to eat the spores in lakes. After feeding, I analyzed the zooplankton using qPCR and detected presence of spores inside the gut. In additional to laboratory experiments, I also collected samples from Lake Inba to determine the number of algal cells that were infected by the parasite and to analyze the free-living spores and grazed spores in a field environment. Preliminary results show successful use of the qPCR method and future studies will continue to refine the method.

 Broader Impacts:

In addition to research, I also participated in many outreach activities while in Japan. I presented my proposed research project at the JSPS poster session during the orientation week of the summer program to other fellows from the U.S., Canada, Germany, France, Britain, and students and faculty of the Sokendai Graduate University in Hayama, Japan. I also presented at the Association for the Sciences of Limnology and Oceanography (ASLO) international meeting in Kyoto and met with many Japanese scientists in my field. At Toho University, I presented two seminars during the summer to the Department of Environmental Science faculty, and graduate and undergraduate students. The first seminar focused on an introduction to my home life and university activities and the second dealt with my dissertation research and the integration of the summer project in Japan. I also contributed to field sampling efforts for general projects of the laboratory. I established a collaboration with my host researcher that will continue throughout my dissertation project. I also attended in a wealth of cultural activities while in Japan including traditional tea ceremonies and music performances. During my trip to the ASLO meeting, I was also able to visit many shrines and temples in Kyoto and attended the annual Gion Festival. I also attended the Grand Sumo Tournament and visited castles in Nagoya and Hiroshima.
